defs.docs: # wasmi

attributes.value: ! This library allows WebAssembly modules to be loaded in binary format and their functions invoked.
! WebAssembly (wasm) is a safe, portable and compact format that is designed for efficient execution.
! Wasm code is distributed in the form of modules that contains definitions of:
! Each of these definitions can be imported and exported.
! In addition to these definitions, modules can define initialization data for their memory or tables. This initialization data can take the
! form of segments, copied to given offsets. They can also define a `start` function that is automatically executed when the module is loaded.
! Before execution, a module must be validated. This process checks that the module is well-formed
! A valid module can't access memory outside its sandbox, can't cause stack underflows
! and can only call functions with correct signatures.
! In order to execute code from a wasm module, it must be instantiated.
! 2. Resolving the definition instances for each declared import in the module.
! 3. Instantiating definitions declared in the module (e.g. allocate global variables, allocate linear memory, etc.).
! 4. Initializing memory and table contents by copying segments into them.
! After these steps, the module instance is ready to execute functions.
! It only is allowed to call functions which are exported by the module.
! Functions can either return a result or trap (e.g. there can't be linking error in the middle of the function execution).
! This property is ensured by the validation process.
!     // Parse WAT (WebAssembly Text format) into wasm bytecode.
!     // Load wasm binary and prepare it for instantiation.
!     // Instantiate a module with empty imports and
!     // assert that there is no `start` function.
!     // Finally, invoke the exported function "test" with no parameters

defs.name: Trap
defs.docs: Error type which can be thrown by wasm code or by host environment.

attributes.value: / Error type which can be thrown by wasm code or by host environment.
/ Under some conditions, wasm execution may produce a `Trap`, which immediately aborts execution.
/ Traps can't be handled by WebAssembly code, but are reported to the embedder.

defs.name: new
defs.docs: Create new trap.

defs.name: kind
defs.docs: Returns kind of this trap.

defs.name: Unreachable
defs.docs: Wasm code executed `unreachable` opcode.

attributes.value: / `unreachable` is a special opcode which always traps upon execution.
/ This opcode have a similar purpose as `ud2` in x86.

defs.name: MemoryAccessOutOfBounds
defs.docs:
Attempt to load or store at the address which
 lies outside of bounds of the memory.

attributes.value: / Attempt to load or store at the address which
/ lies outside of bounds of the memory.
/ Since addresses are interpreted as unsigned integers, out of bounds access
/ can't happen with negative addresses (i.e. they will always wrap).

defs.name: TableAccessOutOfBounds
defs.docs:
Attempt to access table element at index which
 lies outside of bounds.

attributes.value: / Attempt to access table element at index which
/ This typically can happen when `call_indirect` is executed
/ with index that lies out of bounds.
/ Since indexes are interpreted as unsinged integers, out of bounds access
/ can't happen with negative indexes (i.e. they will always wrap).

defs.name: ElemUninitialized
defs.docs: Attempt to access table element which is uninitialized (i.e. `None`).

attributes.value: / Attempt to access table element which is uninitialized (i.e. `None`).
/ This typically can happen when `call_indirect` is executed.

defs.name: DivisionByZero
defs.docs: Attempt to divide by zero.

attributes.value: / This trap typically can happen if `div` or `rem` is executed with

defs.name: InvalidConversionToInt
defs.docs: Attempt to make a conversion to an int failed.

attributes.value: / Attempt to make a conversion to an int failed.
/ - trying to do signed division (or get the remainder) -2<sup>N-1</sup> over -1. This is
/   because the result +2<sup>N-1</sup> isn't representable as a N-bit signed integer.
/ - trying to truncate NaNs, infinity, or value for which the result is out of range into an integer.

defs.name: StackOverflow
defs.docs: Stack overflow.

attributes.value: / This is likely caused by some infinite or very deep recursion.
/ Extensive inlining might also be the cause of stack overflow.

defs.name: UnexpectedSignature
defs.docs: Attempt to invoke a function with mismatching signature.

attributes.value: / Attempt to invoke a function with mismatching signature.
/ This can happen if [`FuncInstance`] was invoked
/ This can always happen with indirect calls. `call_indirect` instruction always
/ specifies the expected signature of function. If `call_indirect` is executed
/ with index that points on function with signature different that is
/ expected by this `call_indirect`, this trap is raised.

defs.name: Host
defs.docs: Error specified by the host.

attributes.value: / Typically returned from an implementation of [`Externals`].

defs.name: TrapKind
defs.value: TrapKind::{Unreachable, MemoryAccessOutOfBounds, TableAccessOutOfBounds, ElemUninitialized, DivisionByZero, InvalidConversionToInt, StackOverflow, UnexpectedSignature, Host}

defs.name: FuncRef
defs.docs: Reference to a function (See [`FuncInstance`] for details).

attributes.value: / Reference to a function (See [`FuncInstance`] for details).
/ This reference has a reference-counting semantics.

defs.name: FuncInstance
defs.docs: Runtime representation of a function.

attributes.value: / Functions are the unit of organization of code in WebAssembly. Each function takes a sequence of values
/ as parameters and either optionally return a value or trap.
/ Functions can call other function including itself (i.e recursive calls are allowed) and imported functions
/ (i.e functions defined in another module or by the host environment).
/ - by the host environment and passed to a wasm module as an import.

defs.name: alloc_host
defs.docs: Allocate a function instance for a host function.

attributes.value: / Allocate a function instance for a host function.
/ When this function instance will be called by the wasm code,
/ the instance of [`Externals`] will be invoked by calling `invoke_index`
/ This call will be made with the `signature` provided here.

defs.docs: Returns [signature] of this function instance.

attributes.value: / This function instance can only be called with matching signatures.

defs.name: invoke_resumable
defs.value: fn <'args> (func: &FuncRef, args: impl Into<Cow<'args, [RuntimeValue]>>) -> Result<FuncInvocation<'args>, Trap>
defs.docs:
Invoke the function, get a resumable handle. This handle can then be used to [`start_execution`]. If a
 Host trap happens, caller can use [`resume_execution`] to feed the expected return value back in, and then
 continue the execution.

attributes.value: / Invoke the function, get a resumable handle. This handle can then be used to [`start_execution`]. If a
/ Host trap happens, caller can use [`resume_execution`] to feed the expected return value back in, and then
/ This is an experimental API, and this functionality may not be available in other WebAssembly engines.
/ Returns `Err` if `args` types is not match function [`signature`].

defs.name: Trap
defs.docs: Trap happened.

defs.name: NotResumable
defs.docs: The invocation is not resumable.

attributes.value: / Invocations are only resumable if a host function is called, and the host function returns a trap of `Host` kind. For other cases, this error will be returned. This includes:
/ - The invocation is directly a host function.
/ - The invocation has not been started.
/ - The invocation returns normally or returns any trap other than `Host` kind.

defs.name: AlreadyStarted
defs.docs: The invocation has already been started.

attributes.value: / The invocation has already been started.

defs.name: ResumableError
defs.docs: A resumable invocation error.

defs.name: FuncInvocation
defs.docs: A resumable invocation handle. This struct is returned by `FuncInstance::invoke_resumable`.

attributes.value: / A resumable invocation handle. This struct is returned by `FuncInstance::invoke_resumable`.

defs.name: is_resumable
defs.docs: Whether this invocation is currently resumable.

attributes.value: / Whether this invocation is currently resumable.

defs.name: resumable_value_type
defs.docs: If the invocation is resumable, the expected return value type to be feed back in.

attributes.value: / If the invocation is resumable, the expected return value type to be feed back in.

defs.name: start_execution
defs.value: fn <'externals, E> (&mut self, externals: &'externals mut E) -> Result<Option<RuntimeValue>, ResumableError>
defs.docs: Start the invocation execution.

defs.name: resume_execution
defs.value: fn <'externals, E> (&mut self, return_val: Option<RuntimeValue>, externals: &'externals mut E) -> Result<Option<RuntimeValue>, ResumableError>
defs.docs: Resume an execution if a previous trap of Host kind happened.

attributes.value: / Resume an execution if a previous trap of Host kind happened.
/ `return_val` must be of the value type [`resumable_value_type`], defined by the host function import. Otherwise,
/ `UnexpectedSignature` trap will be returned. The current invocation must also be resumable
/ [`is_resumable`]. Otherwise, a `NotResumable` error will be returned.

defs.name: GlobalInstance
defs.docs: Runtime representation of a global variable (or `global` for short).

attributes.value: / Runtime representation of a global variable (or `global` for short).
/ Global contains a value of a specified type and flag which specifies whether this
/ global are mutable or immutable. Neither type of the value nor immutability can't be changed
/ Attempt to change value of immutable global or to change type of
/ the value (e.g. assign [`I32`] value to a global that was created with [`I64`] type) will lead to an error.

/ should match. Otherwise, link-time error will occur.

defs.name: resolve_memory
defs.value: fn (&self, module_name: &str, field_name: &str, descriptor: &MemoryDescriptor) -> Result<MemoryRef, Error>
defs.docs: Resolve a memory.

attributes.value: / Returned memory should match requested memory (described by the `descriptor`),
/ i.e. initial size of a returned memory should be equal or larger than requested memory.
/ Furthermore, if requested memory have maximum size, returned memory either should have
/ equal or larger maximum size or have no maximum size at all.
/ If returned memory doesn't match the requested then link-time error will occur.

defs.name: resolve_table
defs.value: fn (&self, module_name: &str, field_name: &str, descriptor: &TableDescriptor) -> Result<TableRef, Error>
defs.docs: Resolve a table.

attributes.value: / Returned table should match requested table (described by the `descriptor`),
/ i.e. initial size of a returned table should be equal or larger than requested table.
/ Furthermore, if requested memory have maximum size, returned memory either should have
/ equal or larger maximum size or have no maximum size at all.
/ If returned table doesn't match the requested then link-time error will occur.

defs.name: MemoryRef

attributes.value: / Reference to a memory (See [`MemoryInstance`] for details).

defs.name: MemoryInstance
defs.docs: Runtime representation of a linear memory (or `memory` for short).

attributes.value: / Runtime representation of a linear memory (or `memory` for short).
/ A memory is a contiguous, mutable array of raw bytes. Wasm code can load and store values
/ from/to a linear memory at any byte address.
/ A trap occurs if an access is not within the bounds of the current memory size.
/ A memory is created with an initial size but can be grown dynamically.
/ The growth can be limited by specifying maximum size.
/ The size of a memory is always a integer multiple of a [page size][`LINEAR_MEMORY_PAGE_SIZE`] - 64KiB.
/ At the moment, wasm doesn't provide any way to shrink the memory.

defs.name: alloc
defs.value: fn (initial: Pages, maximum: Option<Pages>) -> Result<MemoryRef, Error>
defs.docs: Allocate a memory instance.

attributes.value: / The memory allocated with initial number of pages specified by `initial`.
/ Minimal possible value for `initial` is 0 and maximum possible is `65536`.
/ It is possible to limit maximum number of pages this memory instance can have by specifying
/ `maximum`. If not specified, this memory instance would be able to allocate up to 4GiB.

defs.name: initial
defs.docs: Returns number of pages this `MemoryInstance` was created with.

attributes.value: / Returns number of pages this `MemoryInstance` was created with.

defs.name: maximum
defs.docs: Returns maximum amount of pages this `MemoryInstance` can grow to.

attributes.value: / Returns maximum amount of pages this `MemoryInstance` can grow to.
/ Returns `None` if there is no limit set.
/ Maximum memory size cannot exceed `65536` pages or 4GiB.

defs.name: current_size
defs.docs: Returns current linear memory size.

attributes.value: / Maximum memory size cannot exceed `65536` pages or 4GiB.

defs.name: ModuleInstance
defs.docs: A module instance is the runtime representation of a [module][`Module`].

attributes.value: / A module instance is the runtime representation of a [module][`Module`].
/ It is created by instantiating a [module][`Module`], and collects runtime representations
/ of all entities that are imported or defined by the module, namely:
/ In order to instantiate a module you need to provide entities to satisfy
/ every module's imports (i.e. wasm modules don't have optional imports).
/ After module is instantiated you can start invoking it's exported functions with [`invoke_export`].

defs.docs: Instantiate a [module][`Module`].

attributes.value: / Note that in case of successful instantiation this function returns a reference to
/ a module which `start` function is not called.
/ In order to complete instantiatiation `start` function must be called. However, there are
/ situations where you might need to do additional setup before calling `start` function.
/ For such sitations this separation might be useful.
/ Returns `Err` if the module cannot be instantiated.
/ This can happen if one of the imports can't
/ be satisfied (e.g module isn't registered in `imports` [resolver][`ImportResolver`]) or
/ there is a mismatch between requested import and provided (e.g. module requested memory with no
/ maximum size limit, however, was provided memory with the maximum size limit).
/ // ModuleInstance::new returns instance which `start` function isn't called.
/ If you sure that the module doesn't have `start` function you can use [`assert_no_start`] to get
/ // This will panic if the module actually contain `start` function.

defs.name: invoke_export
defs.value: fn <E> (&self, func_name: &str, args: &[RuntimeValue], externals: &mut E) -> Result<Option<RuntimeValue>, Error>
defs.docs: Invoke exported function by a name.

attributes.value: / Invoke exported function by a name.
/ This function finds exported function by a name, and calls it with provided arguments and
/ - there are no export with a given name or this export is not a function,
/ - given arguments doesn't match to function signature,
/ - trap occurred at the execution time,
/ Invoke a function that takes two numbers and returns sum of them.

defs.name: invoke_export_with_stack
defs.value: fn <E> (&self, func_name: &str, args: &[RuntimeValue], externals: &mut E, stack_recycler: &mut StackRecycler) -> Result<Option<RuntimeValue>, Error>
defs.docs: Invoke exported function by a name using recycled stacks.

attributes.value: / Invoke exported function by a name using recycled stacks.

defs.name: export_by_name
defs.docs: Find export by a name.

attributes.value: / Returns `None` if there is no export with such name.

defs.name: NotStartedModuleRef
defs.docs: Mostly instantiated [`ModuleRef`].

attributes.value: / At this point memory segments and tables are copied. However, `start` function (if any) is not called.
/ To get [fully instantiated module instance][`ModuleRef`], [running `start` function][`run_start`] is required.
/ You can still access not fully initialized instance by calling [`not_started_instance`],
/ but keep in mind, that this is sort of escape hatch: module really might depend on initialization
/ done in `start` function. It's definitely not recommended to call any exports on [`ModuleRef`]
/ If you sure, that there is no `start` function (e.g. because you created it without one), you can
/ call [`assert_no_start`] which returns [`ModuleRef`] without calling `start` function. However,
/ it will panic if module contains `start` function.

defs.name: not_started_instance
defs.docs: Returns not fully initialized instance.

attributes.value: / To fully initialize the instance you need to call either [`run_start`] or

defs.name: run_start
defs.docs: Executes `start` function (if any) and returns fully instantiated module.

attributes.value: / Executes `start` function (if any) and returns fully instantiated module.

defs.name: assert_no_start
defs.docs: Returns fully instantiated module without running `start` function.

attributes.value: / Returns fully instantiated module without running `start` function.
/ This function panics if original module contains `start` function.

defs.name: has_start
defs.docs: Whether or not the module has a `start` function.

attributes.value: / Whether or not the module has a `start` function.
/ Returns `true` if it has a `start` function.

Limit stacks created by this recycler to

 - `call_stack_limit` levels for calls.

defs.name: clear
defs.docs:
Clears any values left on the stack to avoid
 leaking them to future export invocations.

attributes.value: / Clears any values left on the stack to avoid
/ leaking them to future export invocations.
/ This is a secondary defense to prevent modules from
/ exploiting faulty stack handling in the interpreter.
/ Do note that there are additional channels that
/ can leak information into an untrusted module.

defs.name: TableRef
defs.docs: Reference to a table (See [`TableInstance`] for details).

attributes.value: / Reference to a table (See [`TableInstance`] for details).
/ This reference has a reference-counting semantics.

defs.name: TableInstance
defs.docs: Runtime representation of a table.

attributes.value: / A table is a array of untyped functions. It allows wasm code to call functions
/ indirectly through a dynamic index into a table. For example, this allows emulating function
/ pointers by way of table indices.
/ Table is created with an initial size but can be grown dynamically via [`grow`] method.
/ Growth can be limited by an optional maximum size.
/ In future, a table might be extended to be able to hold not only functions but different types.

defs.name: alloc
defs.value: fn (initial_size: u32, maximum_size: Option<u32>) -> Result<TableRef, Error>
defs.docs: Allocate a table instance.

attributes.value: / The table allocated with initial size, specified by `initial_size`.
/ Maximum size can be specified by `maximum_size`.
/ All table elements are allocated uninitialized.

defs.name: initial_size
defs.docs: Returns size this table was created with.

attributes.value: / Returns size this table was created with.

defs.name: maximum_size
defs.docs: Returns maximum size `TableInstance` can grow to.

attributes.value: / Returns maximum size `TableInstance` can grow to.

defs.name: current_size
defs.docs: Returns current size of the table.

attributes.value: / Returns current size of the table.

defs.name: grow
defs.docs: Increases the size of the table by given number of elements.

attributes.value: / Increases the size of the table by given number of elements.
/ Returns `Err` if tried to allocate more elements than permited by limit.

defs.name: RuntimeValue
defs.docs: Runtime representation of a value.

attributes.value: / Wasm code manipulate values of the four basic value types:
/ integers and floating-point (IEEE 754-2008) data of 32 or 64 bit width each, respectively.
/ There is no distinction between signed and unsigned integer types. Instead, integers are
/ interpreted by respective operations as either unsigned or signed in twos complement representation.
